qas.question: How many families were without a bread winner?
How many water-powered cotton mills used child labour in 1788 England and Scotland?
Was it a low amount or high amount of children that also worked in prostitution?
Where was Charles Dickens employed as a child?
During the Industrial Revolution what was the main driving force behind child labour?

context: Child labour played an important role in the Industrial Revolution from its outset, often brought about by <a4_0>economic hardship<a4_0/>. The children of the poor were expected to contribute to their family income. In 19th-century Great Britain, <a0_0>one-third<a0_0/> of poor families were without a breadwinner, as a result of death or abandonment, obliging many children to work from a young age. In England and Scotland in 1788, two-thirds of the workers in <a1_0>143<a1_0/> water-powered cotton mills were described as children. A <a2_0>high number<a2_0/> of children also worked as prostitutes. The author Charles Dickens worked at the age of 12 in a <a3_0>blacking factory<a3_0/>, with his family in debtor's prison.
